extendedIngredients.name: boneless pork shoulder
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3.5 pound boneless pork shoulder ( or substitute beef roast)

extendedIngredients.name: cabbage
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3 cups cabbage, shredded or finely sliced

extendedIngredients.name: chili garlic sauce
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 tablespoons Sriracha or chili garlic sauce

extendedIngredients.name: ready-to-serve Asian fried rice
extendedIngredients.originalString: Serve with warm or toasted corn/flower tortillas, pickled onions, cilantro, lime, avocado slices ( optional)
metaInformation: with warm or toasted corn/flower tortillas, pickled onions, cilantro, lime, avocado slices ( optional)

extendedIngredients.name: red onions
extendedIngredients.originalString: ¼ cup red onions sliced thin or 3 scallions, chopped

extendedIngredients.name: thai basil
extendedIngredients.originalString: ¼ cup chopped cilantro, mint or thai basil

recipes.title: SLOW-ROASTED FIVE SPICE PULLED PORK (OR BEEF) TACOS

winePairing.pairingText: Tacos works really well with Pinot Noir, Riesling, and Sparkling rosé. Acidic white wines like riesling or low-tannin reds like pinot noir can work well with Mexican dishes. Sparkling rosé is a safe pairing too. You could try Dutton-Goldfield Dutton Ranch Pinot Noir. Reviewers quite like it with a 4.4 out of 5 star rating and a price of about 43 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Dutton-Goldfield Dutton Ranch Pinot Noir
productMatches.description: The ripening season was classic Russian River, with warm days and cool nights—and with no major heat spells, the fruit ripening was perfect to give lush tannins, bright berry fruit and bright acidity. The wine shows rich, dense black cherry and blackberry fruit and nuances of strawberry, raspberry, and nutmeg in the nose. In the mouth, the first impression is fresh berry fruit, then the soft, broad tannins carry notes of marionberries, nutmeg and sandalwood through a lingering finish. Thanks partially to the moderate alcohol and bright acidity, the finish lingers with fresh cherry fruit and creamy berry compote.This wine has a broad range of food pairings, whether alone with some well chosen cheeses, richer fish preparations or a good old steak on the barbeque.

recipes.instructions: Mix salt, sugar and 5 spice together. Coat all sides of the Pork roast well, discarding excess. Place in a small baking dish and cover with plastic wrap ( or wrap the whole roast in plastic wrap) refrigerate overnight (or for at least 2 hours). Bake in a 250F oven for 6 hours, uncovered, basting with the flavorful pan juices once every couple hours. Pull it from the oven and let it cool a bit. ( Alternatively, if using a slow cooker, cook for 4-5 hours on high, or 7 hours on low, adding a  cup water to the bottom first) Shred the pork with two forks. Mix in the vinegar.Keep warm in the oven, slow cooker, or refrigerate, and reheat before serving.To make the slaw, mix all the ingredients in a medium bowl, and let stand a few minutes before serving, to allow flavors to meld.To make the sauce, mix mayo, sriracha and vinegar in a small bowl.Toast tortillas in a toaster oven, or grill" directly over a gas flame, over the stove until warm.Place a little sauce on the tortilla, top with pulled pork and slaw. Garnish with avocado slice ( optional) and fresh cilantro and lime wedges.Notes: To get the pork crispy, saute in a skillet, letting it brown up, right before serving.

steps.step: Mix salt, sugar and 5 spice together. Coat all sides of the Pork roast well, discarding excess.
Place in a small baking dish and cover with plastic wrap ( or wrap the whole roast in plastic wrap) refrigerate overnight (or for at least 2 hours).

Bake in a 250F oven for 6 hours, uncovered, basting with the flavorful pan juices once every couple hours. Pull it from the oven and let it cool a bit. ( Alternatively, if using a slow cooker, cook for 4-5 hours on high, or 7 hours on low, adding a  cup water to the bottom first) Shred the pork with two forks.

Mix in the vinegar.Keep warm in the oven, slow cooker, or refrigerate, and reheat before serving.To make the slaw, mix all the ingredients in a medium bowl, and let stand a few minutes before serving, to allow flavors to meld.To make the sauce, mix mayo, sriracha and vinegar in a small bowl.Toast tortillas in a toaster oven, or grill" directly over a gas flame, over the stove until warm.
Place a little sauce on the tortilla, top with pulled pork and slaw.
Garnish with avocado slice ( optional) and fresh cilantro and lime wedges.Notes: To get the pork crispy, saute in a skillet, letting it brown up, right before serving.
